message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings of atypical lymphocytes suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. In an immunocompromised host, the Epstein-Barr virus can cause linear ulcers near the lower esophageal sphincter. Multiple cerebral abscesses with surrounding edema and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates with pneumatoceles are more commonly caused by bacterial or fungal infections. Purplish skin nodules on the distal extremities are a manifestation of Kaposi sarcoma, which is commonly seen in HIV-positive patients.
